thread.title: Younger savers urged to buckle in and weather the storm
thread.title_full: Younger savers urged to buckle in and weather the storm | afr.com

author: Sally Rose
title: Younger savers urged to buckle in and weather the storm
text:
Investors in their 20s, 30s and 40s are advised not to get spooked by short-term market volatility. iStock Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Sally Rose
Maximising real returns – after fees, taxes and inflation – is more important than ever for young savers as the global economy heads into what is tipped to be an extended period of low growth and low inflation that will dampen investment returns over the next decade.
Investment professionals urge people in their 20s, 30s and 40s not to panic about the challenging years ahead, but to make sure they have the right investment strategy in place for their long-term goals.
Other ways to maximise a nest egg including starting to put a little extra away as early as possible plus keeping a careful eye on how much is being lost in fees and taxes.
"It is really important that younger savers don't get too spooked by short-term volatility and take their eye off the main game, which is making sure their wealth beats inflation over the next 40 to 50 years or longer," says Elston Financial chief executive Andrew McKie.
Leading asset consultants including Towers Watson, Frontier Advisers and Rice Warner have all warned that major superannuation funds may need to lower their targeted investment returns over the next three to 10 years .
This presents the greatest challenge to people who are at or nearing retirement, but will also hurt younger savers.
Over the past decade average returns have been 8 per cent. Under that scenario, a $100,000 balance would be worth $1.478 million in 35 years. But if returns are 6.5 per cent, that balance will be worth $906,225 in 35 years.
 Picking the right long-term investment strategy typically determines 80 per cent to 90 per cent of an investor's total return outcome over the long term, McKie adds.
Younger super savers need to maintain a long-term allocation skewed towards growth assets such as property and shares because they provide a hedge against inflation, he says.
"Adopting too conservative an investment strategy that won't keep pace with inflation is actually one of the biggest risks for younger savers," Steward Wealth director James Weir says.
Reducing the cost of fees and taxes is also important. "When nominal returns are 10 per cent, paying an investment fee of 1.5 per cent costs 15 per cent of investment returns," McKie says. "But if nominal returns sink to 5 per cent, the same fee will eat up 30 per cent of the lower investment returns."
Just as important as managing fees is managing tax. "People can boost their after-tax returns by managing capital gains, boosting franking credits and focusing on tax-loss harvesting," Weir says.
Increasing the after-tax return on a $100,00 super balance over 35 years by just 1 percentage point, from 5 per cent to 6 per cent, would result in a 39 per cent increase in the final balance from $551,601 to $768,608, he adds.
Still, probably the most effective way to grow a super balance over time is to increase contributions.
"Start putting as much away as you can, as early as you can, to take advantage of the tax benefits of super and let compounding interest work its magic," Weir says.
The value of $1 invested when you are 50 is worth about $2.50 by age 65, whereas if that $1 had been invested at age 20 it would be worth about $18 by age 65, he adds.
